texts.definition: The underlying structures of stories that games contain or can create.
markups: <style="Definition">The underlying structures of stories that games contain or can create.</style>
Games can both contain stories and create new ones as they are being played. In both cases the gameplay structure of the games can influence these <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style>.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

Records of game instances of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> can be seen as <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> but this may be even more apparent when the chess pieces are presented as characters. "Through the Looking-Glass" by Lewis Carroll is an example of this although some artistic freedom is taken in the alternation of players moving. Another example is that Samuel Beckett includes an annotated <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> record in the novel "Murphy", and "Reunion" (a project by among others John Cage and Marcel Duchamp) used the structures emerging from <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> game instances to create music.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> through "adventures" or "campaigns" that consist of a series of "adventures". They are rather unique as <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> in that they have detailed descriptions of interesting locations, important characters, and possible events but typically not the player characters since these are to be created by players for each game instance. Examples of adventures include "The Keep on the Borderlands", "Rahasia", and "Ravenloft" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and "The Rise of R'lyeh" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>, and examples of campaign include "Queen of the Spiders" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, "Masks of Nyarlathotep" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style> and "The Enemy Within campaign" for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warhammer%20Fantasy%20Roleplay">Warhammer Fantasy Roleplay</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">Live Action Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/1942%20%E2%80%93%20Noen%20%C3%A5%20stole%20p%C3%A5">1942 – Noen å stole på</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Prosopopeia">Prosopopeia</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mind's%20Eye%20Theatre">Mind's Eye Theatre</link></style> can have planned events but rely heavily on players providing additional input and substance to the narration.

Both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Myst%20series">Myst</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/King's%20Quest%20series">King's Quest</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leisure%20Suit%20Larry%20series">Leisure Suit Larry</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Secret%20of%20Monkey%20Island%20series">The Secret of Monkey Island series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Final%20Fantasy%20series">Final Fantasy series</link></style> have detailed pre-planned narratives. In contrast <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/MUD2">MUD2</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> have many <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> to tell players through quests but players can to certain extent create their own narratives in these games as well.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> in games can both be created or told as gameplay evolves. <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emergent%20Gameplay">Emergent Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Constructed%20Worlds">Player-Constructed Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Generated%20Narratives">Player-Generated Narratives</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> are all patterns to support the former while the use of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> is the primary way in which narratives are revealed through the gameplay. <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> can be used to not only reveal or present <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> as appropriate, they can be used to choose between different ones depending on context. In addition, they can create new <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> as needed if they have the right abilities; <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> naturally do but computer-based ones need algorithms to create new structures.  <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style> can enforce <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> independent of how they are told, while the structures inherent in goals like <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> can help provide <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> and <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style> can modulate and support each other. <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style> can support <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> by being linked to specific parts of <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> and thereby ensure that players will experience these narrations and that the completion of these goals are connected if not integrated with the narration. In contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> can support <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style> by provide both diegetic reasons why players would want to complete the <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style> as well as provide information related to how these goals can be achieved (the <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> can of course also include <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>).

As a special type of <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="main-goals">Main Goals</link></style> can have the same relations to <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> as <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style> but these relations are more likely to be seen as necessary requirements in a game design since they are a primary way to connect a game's narration with what should be a primary motivation for players' actions in the game.

<style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> can similarly provide support to the designs of goals such as <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>.

Having game elements that can carry the <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> is a requirement for the pattern. Most essential is the presence of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> that can have goals and <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> that can perform actions in accordance to these; <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style> can create structures during gameplay, so together with <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> the process can become a joint one but a signification design choice for using <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> is to decide if players should have such <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>. When players are given such control, it is quite common to also have <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>.

The possibility of <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> can heavily affect <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> if permitted, but when the <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> are set before gameplay it can work against having <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> as a possibility. Linked to this is the question if <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> should have <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destinies</link></style> since this may be most relevant to consider for <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style> can be the source of these goals while <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style> can explain settings different from the real world. <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> are also very common since they can provide resistance to players and can easily be created through introducing <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style> between <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, while <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> can bring life to narratives by adding detail. <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> can be used to separate different parts of gameplay and <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> from each other in a game while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style> situations can create uncertainty on how the narration will progress. <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> that are to introduce new elements as gameplay and narration progresses need some type of <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>.

Some events may be desirable for <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> regardless if they are pre-planned or ones that game designers wish will occur from circumstances regarding gameplay because they will make the narratives memorable. Examples of such events include <style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style> and designers may consider both designing these and making it more likely that situations in which they can occur will happen. More generally, the use of <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style> can tie player goals into the <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> both by being triggered by specific events in the narration as well as having as a goal a game state than is suitable for a next intended narrative event.

Games that support <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style> at least partly work against <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> since the <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style> activity specifically does not result in noteworthy events.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>
<style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> is often a requirement for <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> to be intelligible or enjoyable for people.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> is not an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Interface%20Patterns">Interface Pattern</link></style> but a game's choice of <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> can affect which types of <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> can work, e.g. <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> do not work with <style="Link"><link="god-views">God Views</link></style>.

The use of <style="Link"><link="feigned-die-rolls">Feigned Die Rolls</link></style> allow <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> to ignore <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> in favor of developing a narration in accordance with their own wishes.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Narration%20Patterns">Narration Pattern</link></style>. Using <style="Link"><link="non-consistent-narration">Non-Consistent Narration</link></style> is an option for <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style>  which mainly concerns its structural aspects, and <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="melodramatic-structures">Melodramatic Structures</link></style> are two different forms of <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> based on how players get information. In most cases, <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> are designed to have <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style>. The actual structure of a narration is likely to influence or create <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> in a game, meaning that the two patterns can instantiate each other depending on which part of a game design is initiated first (and <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style> are especially likely to create or affect <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style>).
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> of any type in a game offers a chance for players' to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style> and often contain both <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="closure-points">Closure Points</link></style>, the latter which in turn can be <style="Link"><link="goal-indicators">Goal Indicators</link></style>. The context provided by <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> can provide <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> and cause <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> but so can also just wanting to know what will happen next or how the narrative will end. However, <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> can also work against <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> if the <style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> contains no <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> or if players that want to interact with a game system is hindered from this due to the narration.

<style="CurrentLink">Narration Structures</style> can work as a supporting structure for <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, helping players understand the evolving gameplay not only from a game system perspective but a narrative one as well. One such example is using the narration to explain why individual players have may <style="Link"><link="secret-goals">Secret Goals</link></style> (note that this pattern relates to gameplay goals not narrative goals).
<style="H2">Relations</style>
<style="H3">Can Instantiate</style>

<style="Link"><link="closure-points">Closure Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="goal-indicators">Goal Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hovering-closures">Hovering Closures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Narrative%20Engrossment">Narrative Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secret-goals">Secret Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Modulate</style>

<style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="main-goals">Main Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Instantiated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="algorithmic-agents">Algorithmic Agents</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="construction">Construction</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emergent%20Gameplay">Emergent Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Constructed%20Worlds">Player-Constructed Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Generated%20Narratives">Player-Generated Narratives</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rescue">Rescue</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="speedruns">Speedruns</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ultra-powerful-events">Ultra-Powerful Events</link></style>
<style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Modulated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="betrayal">Betrayal</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="detective-structures">Detective Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="feigned-die-rolls">Feigned Die Rolls</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-insertion">Game Element Insertion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="goal-hierarchies">Goal Hierarchies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="higher-level-closures-gameplay-progresses">Higher-Level Closures as Gameplay Progresses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="incompatible-goals">Incompatible Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leaps%20of%20Faith">Leaps of Faith</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="main-goals">Main Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mandatory-goals">Mandatory Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="melodramatic-structures">Melodramatic Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-consistent-narration">Non-Consistent Narration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="open-destiny">Open Destiny</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-dilemmas">Social Dilemmas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>
<style="H3">Possible Closure Effects</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Potentially Conflicting With</style>

<style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pottering">Pottering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>
